Well I won't be around much.  Turns out HP was aware of huge issue with my laptop model that results in it becoming one giant paperweight.  Of course I don't discover said issue until 2 years after warranty ends.  So I'm left with choice $400 to repair lappy (a fix according some internet forums doesn't work forever) or saving up to replace it with an IPAD or something else. 

Its just so frustrating.  Now I have to beg, borrow or steal computer time from my Mom and Brother, both of whom are students.  So I probably won't be around as much because they're usually on theirs when I'm home and not sure what I can/should access from work.  I looked forward to using my laptop after my 1-2 hour commute home depending on traffic and now its gone.  To console myself I bought another writing book this ones full of exercises so I can apply what I'm learning.  Only now I have to write by hand.  Boy now I'm just depressing myself more.

TTFN

Thank Goodness It's Payday!  Mom watched a PBS special, wanted to buy the book so we went to both Borders and Barnes & Noble to find it.  Glad we checked both because she found it for 30% off which meant I didn't have to feel guilty about the two writing books I picked up for myself.  

One is called "Story Structure Architect: A writer's guide to building dramatic situations & compelling characters." The other sounds promising in other ways "Breathing Life Into Your Characters: How to give your characters emotional & psychological depth."  In re-reading some of my favorite stories I've noticed they are ones that have strong characters and story development.  In looking at my own work I can see those along with planning are not my strongest suits.  So I'm reading up to see if I can improve those areas and others.

Watched the uncut version of "Quigley Down Under" there were a bunch of scenes that they cut or edited that really added to the story so it made more sense. A good reminder that less isn't always best.

I'm so sorry I haven't posted in ages, but things have been very hectic in real life. Since Christmas my Grandmother had surgery for breast cancer, I fell and gave myself a concussion, changed jobs, crashed into a garbage truck (I was fine, car got repaired), lost my steering belt (part not fixed in crash repairs, learned a couple of computer programs, totally revamped our student hospitals/clinic process and had open house to tell the colleges we work with and that's just the highlights. So I been really busy, but then I got this fabulous card from Jen. Thanks Jen you reminded me how much I missed my lj & csi friends, missed writing and reading. So when I was at the library yesterday I snagged some books on writing and editing. I want to share with you the opening from Jill Jepson's "Writing as a Sacred Path" which really reminded me of why I love/miss writing. "If you are reading this book, you have already heard the call. Maybe, at this point, it's just a whisper, a small voice quietly urging you to put your ideas into words...Or perhaps the voice is more insistent. Characters appear full-blown in our consciousness, complete with faces and bodies, histories and dreams. It isn't so much that you've thought the characters up as they have arrived uninvited. You wake up to find them sitting at the foot of your bed saying, "Well? Have you given us substance yet?" You long to put is all down on paper. You have to tell their stories....This impulse (writing) may sound like masochism or addiction, and perhaps it is, but it is also something greater and more compelling: it's a vocation, a calling." During my new extended commute (35-90 minutes depending on Bay Area traffic) I heard the voices of my old posted and unwritten stories calling. My goal is to find times and ways to give them voice again. Part of that will involve reading the book above during lunch because she reminded me why I need to write and why I love reading what the rest of you write. Now I'm off to read your recent posts!

There are a number of reasons for my silence the last few months and all of them are related to a single, dreaded 4-letter word.  WORK... Basically each month there has been some time consuming project that has sucked the life out of me so that when I finally got home most days I came home, ate dinner and went to sleep.  When work was quiet, then family stuff picked up; the upside is mom has finally got to know things about her father and meet some of his other kids.  This of course has lead to more family drama.  I'm still recovering from some bug picked up from work, which is one of the bad things about working in a hospital.  So this is just a brief note to anyone who might be "listening" to let you know I'm alive and working on GSR stories when time allows.  TTFN

's reply made me realize that I've been pretty quiet about what's been happening so I'll take a few minutes to bring you up to date.  Since the old department Director left my role at work has changed drastically, I went from being just clerical support to having input on how the department functions.  Our department is active in many aspects of hospital administration, but because the old Director kept us in the dark we didn't really get to interact with hospital leadership.  Now, however, we're slowly navigating uncharted waters.  Our Assistant Director is still very new, she's only been with the company and California for 10 months so part of my job is to explain how to succeed in our corporate environment so I've become one of the leaders in our department.  Part of what makes this so hard is that the hospital leadership has been working on ways to improve how our hospital performs to better serve our members.  In many ways this is exciting because we're trying new things, but change in an unsettled environment can be exhausting, so some of us end up working harder and longer to smooth things over.

At least my personal life has been pretty quiet.  Nothing is happening in my love life (which may be a good thing) though my brother's spending more and more time with his girlfriend.  My health is okay except for the bad cold I had last week and I'm grateful Mom's still not showing too many affects from her strokes though she's excited about finding a new sister. 

She has the strangest family story, I won't bore you with all the details, but long story short her father was kind of a bigamist.  How can you be kind of a bigamist you ask, well you have wedding ceremonies and marriages, but neglect to file all the paperwork.  A couple months before her first stroke Mom posted a question on Yahoo! Answers looking for assistance in tracking her father down.  A very nice person gave us the genealogy info they'd found.  It wasn't until the following July that she found the response posted the month after her stroke from her half-brother Bill.  The result was the discovery that she had new brothers, sisters, nieces, nephews, cousins and info about that side of the family. 

Fast forward to the other day and Mom's opening an e-mail from a new long lost sister who no one seems to have known about who knows more about that side of the family because she was close to her father's sister.  Interestingly enough this is an aunt and couple of uncles that Bill didn't know about.  She also knows about a wife and more siblings who were in Washington (Bill is in Nevada).  So I do a little digging on some websites and found new listings for my grandfather in posted marriage, divorce and birth certificate census lists which gave us more previously unknown wives and another lost sister who was born in Texas.  We're pretty sure its the same guy because his middle name isn't that common and when Mom talks to her new siblings too many details match up.  So on that front the saga continues.

As for the writing, well I'm still having trouble getting more than two paragraphs down at a time.  It's kind of this weird block.  In the past I used to kind of "hear" my stories, the way the words flowed.  I think though things on that front are getting better because I've been getting new inspiration for old and new stories and been hearing pieces of the story. Just the other morning I was driving and heard a section for When the Evidence Lies which will take that story in a new direction, found a couple of songs that are revitalizing both Sara's Little Diversion and some of the ones I've worked on but not posted.

I guess the answer to your question mingsmommy is that I'm hanging in there and things are getting better every day.  I hope you all can say the same thing.

So Mom turned over to this new show on ABC called The Unusuals. I love it! It's like "Dead Like Me" meets "NYPD Blue" this is not your average cop show. This cops are sarcastic with realistic characters and real foibles, yet the cases are interesting. If you're looking for something to watch instead of CSI:NY or Law and Order give this show a try. A show hasn't caught my attention this quickly since CSI premiered.

Show: The Unusuals, 2009
Network: ABC
Genre(s): Drama

Starring: Amber Tamblyn, Jeremy Renner, Harold Perrineau, Joshua Close, Monique Gabriela Curnen, Kai Lennox, Terry Kinney, Adam Goldberg

Summary: Like a modern-day "M*A*S*H," "The Unusuals" explores both the grounded drama and comic insanity of the world of New York City police detectives, where every cop has a secret. It also helps to have a twisted sense of humor, since every day could be your last.

Detective Casey Shraeger (Amber Tamblyn) has just been transferred to the NYPD's Homicide unit from Vice and is instantly thrown into a setting of bullets and bodies. As she begins her new assignment, Casey finds that the squad is full of secrets, which serves her well, since she's keeping a few of her own. "The Unusuals" premieres WEDNESDAY, APRIL 8 (10:02-11:00 p.m., ET), on the ABC Television Network.

The last few months have flown by and it seems like I've hardly had a chance to take a breath.  Basically since my last post things at work got very strained and then even weirder.  Between January and February things got tenser at work, until one day my manager started a conversation which included a statement that since I was having difficulty finding a new job, she'd be happy to give me a list of head hunters.  At the time this felt like a barely veiled threat against my job.  I ended up talking to the Director of Human Resources about the issues I was having with the manager.  Shortly after that to everyone's surprise she announces that she's suddenly decided to resign her position. Her last day was Thursday, so for the last month I've been trying to support her as she prepped to leave and assisting the woman who is replacing her in getting settled.  The good news is my job is secure, my evaluation was okay and I work a lot better with the new boss.  Already this change is reducing my stress and writer's block.

The other exciting but more recent change was I upgraded my phone, since Verizon was doing the blackberry buy one, get one free deal I bought blackberry storm's for my brother and I.  Its a big change from my old phone, but there are some pluses I'm looking forward too.  I'm trying to get better connected so I've started a twitter account in the hope I can update LJ more often.  If anyone has any suggestions or tips I'd be grateful for the help.  Switching from a regular phone to a blackberry is a bigger change than I bargained for.

talk to you soon!

My resolution for this year kind of sounds simple, but doesn't really express the multi-faceted program I'm attempting to improve myself. 
  • Continue to improve health by keeping daily fat intake to <40 grams with goal being 20 grams daily
  • Increase physical health and activity
  • Improve emotional health by practicing gratitude and affirming the positive
  • Make creativity more important to daily life
  • Get out and enjoy life more
I've managed to stay on the low-fat diet for the last year and try to be very conscious about what I am eating.  I think last year's success make this an easy one to continue, though I've decided to add to it with an activity component.  Once I do the orientation at work I can use the employee gym its only offered a couple times a month and I've missed the earlier ones due to meetings and stuff because we have to do it on our own time.  That should happen this week with any luck otherwise I have to wait til the 4th Wed.  in the mean time I've been using the stairs more and parking in the furthest garage so I have a longer walk into work.  My motto for that is small steps, which I'll probably start tracking now that I've found my pedometer again.  The Docs at work like to promote the 10,000 steps program for increasing health.

The last year has taken a toll on my optimism at times; I look at where I am, where I want to go and realizing that my 15 year high school reunion should be this summer and very little has been accomplished towards my desires is disheartening.  So I'm taking some old advice and retraining my mind for an attitude of gratitude.  I'm even looking at getting involved in organized religion again, though that's hard for me because I've had troubles fitting in with groups that have certain unshakable beliefs.  I respect their convictions, but have spent so many years asking why that its ingrained.  We'll see how that works.

To increase my creativity I'm trying to explore new hobbies while re-energizing old hobbies, I'll try and share any advancements here.  On the writing front that has me returning to When the Evidence Lies and doing some editing and adding to the existing chapters.  I'm holding on posting the changes until I've gotten through it all, but I am seeing things I missed the first time around and hope readers will like the new version and chapters once they are up.

I'm not sure how I'll accomplish the getting out and enjoying life more at this point, but I think it will encompass the other goals for now and expand letter.  Part of the getting out is by trying to post here more regularly and trying to establish or re-establish online friendships again.  I've had that goal before, so we'll see if I can accomplish it better this time.

Mostly I want to remember to appreciate each day and be joyful, because life happens.

2009 has really only just begun and so far "It Could'va Been Worse" seems to be the current motto.  I've been meaning to post, but haven't been up to much of anything since I took the new job.  At first I thought the exhaustion was because of the longer commute, learning the new job and getting to know the dynamics and politics of a new department.  Now I recognize that while trying to choose the job that best met my list of wants and needs, I managed to leap out of the pan and into the fire.  I thought the change would be good, but it hasn't been.  Basically my new boss is a micro-managing control freak who doesn't need or appreciate my skill set.  I'd only been there 3 weeks when I realized what a huge mistake I'd made, but it was too late to correct it without starting another job search.  That was right about the time the news about the economy hit and I knew I was stuck.   I think that more than anything lead to a kind of bleak, depression.  I can't improve my situation at work, but can't leave because Mom and brother are depending on me.
Their dependence on me lead to bleak realization number two.  My brother who is 11 years younger than me has had more serious relationships than I have.  He's currently involved with a RN and it looks from the outside to be pretty serious.  Which has made me look at the future and consider the possibility that given mom's health issues that I may end up just being her caretaker forever.  That fact felt very real earlier this week, when Mom was admitted to the hospital for a second stroke.  During her 2 day hospital visit I divided my time between work, the hospital and home where I had to be the rock everyone's used to depending on.  While my brother went to school instead work and spent time with his girlfriend.  Between the cell phone and sharing an apartment we communicated for less than 10 minutes and most of that was coordinating who'd get Mom from the hospital.  My boss basically made it impossible for me to leave work so Michael had to do the discharge stuff this time.  I don't begrudge Mom for needing the care or my brother for getting emotional support where he could, but the selfish part of me looks at my life and is frustrated because less than 5 days into the new year and already my resolution to improve myself has crashed and burned. 

Mom's stroke was mild and it looks like she dodged another bullet.  There's no obvious issues; she can move, talk and do things fo which I'm grateful, but I still feel depressed and stressed by it all.  The reality is that her finding a job to help with the family expenses is even more unlikely.  She's been applying and interviewing for a year with no luck.  Michael's change in emphasis to Nursing has extended his time at college and he's having to increase his course load to graduate soon.  And me well school's out for now, the job's too stressful.  Part of my focus this year was going to be on improving my social life, because since moving here I've become a hermit with little contact with people outside of work.  But right now escaping into romantic or paranormal fiction seems to be the order of the day. 

Gosh, scrolling up I'm seeing nothing but a depressing rant under the cut, but there really are bright spots to my life.  I've met some interesting people at work, shared some stuff that has them making improvements (changing their attitude, the way they deal with fool and going back to grad school) to in their own lives, which in turn has lead to some improvements at work.  Not enough to keep me in the department indefinitely, so I'm still looking at transferring to another job since this one doesn't allow me the flexibility I need if Mom's health gets worse.  I am working at trying to be more creative by getting back into writing, journaling and learning two new hobbies watercolor painting and wire jewelry making.  Most of the time I'm content with my life, its only that sometimes I look at others and wish for more, but most of the time   For now though I'm taking it one day at time or one moment depending on what's happening and just being appreciative of all that I do have because it really could be worse.

I got the results back and apparently the results of both the EEGs and MRI were normal.  Not sure what the Doctor will tell me on Thursday, but at least I don't have a brain tumor or something equally scary.  I suspect I'll get the same speech I got last year about how it will go away on its own or maybe he'll tell me to keep taking the meds (according to one pharm site they don't know how it works, just that it does treat pain and epilepsy).  I'm still having the electric shocks, though not as many and the med side effects are finally (after 4 weeks) are going away too.  I actually drove myself to and from work last week, which I haven't done in weeks because of the lack of co-ordination and dizziness.  Poor Mom's had to get up at 5am to drive me in.

So I've been kinda depressed because at the last couple of Doctor's visits I haven't seen any weight loss or there's weight gain on the scale.  Yet I have been noticing a difference in my clothes (a little odd since no exercise, just trying to keep fat about 20g per day).  It started with a couple of shirts that used to be skin tight being comfy and then loose, I've been able to steal some of Mom's clothes and wear some of my smaller 2X (18-20) stuff. 

Which was why I cleared the closet and donated to charity of all the stuff I was wearing last summer (3X and 4X).  I made myself try on everything including the stuff I've been carting around for 6 years on the chance I might someday be able to wear it again.  Before learning about PCOS I didn't really have much hope of ever fitting into them.  So I was shocked when I tried them and found they were just a little bit tight.  About this same time I informed my boss and co-workers in our team meeting that I would accept the first job I was offered.  I wanted to warn them because they'll probably have to go from working every 3rd to every other weekend to cover my shifts. 

Anyway last week I needed an interview outfit and decided to try on my favorite black suit pants and blue silk blouse just to see if they might fit.  They did and when paired with my black 3" slings I felt like I'd had a Tim Gunn makeover.  I felt ab fab; tall (the shoes put me close to 5'7"), glowing with youth & vitality (bare essentials is great makeup) and more like myself than I have in ages.    

They're gonna make a decision later this week and I have a good shot since one of the managers works closely with my old boss.  Plus the job combines bits from every job I've done in the company including the excel spreadsheets with pivot tables I designed.  So I'm really qualified, but even if I don't get it I'm not worried because I got calls yesterday to schedule an interview for next week and another letting me know they'll be calling later this week to schedule an interview.  I'm not the only one with job news.  Mom got called in for an interview for today (her first since the stroke).  I'm really hoping she gets it because I think it will help her take the next step in recovering.  My brother just got hired for his college's emergency services department, its only 10 hours a week, but he's really looking forward to it.  It feels really great after weeks of stressing over how to pay the bills to finally have some good news.

The interview next week is for the job I really, really want because it would mean a $5 an hour raise and if i ended up on swing or graves its even more $$, it includes a uniform allowance (so no more thinking about what to wear to work), similar benefits so I only lose 8 days of time off per year and I would actually be working in the same field as the degree I'm working on.  The only downside is that unlike the others it means leaving the company I've been with for 11 years.  In some ways the company has been very good to me, but I really think its time to try something new.  So I'm keeping my fingers crossed.

There is also good news on the writing front.  I located the flash drive with all my writing and story notes so I can resume editting and writing my WIPs (its been missing for a month, but I've had other things on my mind).  I was feeling so good the last two days that I actually got some writing done.  I'm not quite ready to post anything yet, but at least the story that I've been thinking about doing since Goodbye and Goodluck is finally off to a good start its suppose to be a case file with hints about Sara's ghosts, I also worked on some other unposted stuff and am debating editting and reposting some of my WIPs.  That idea became more appealing after I got this rude review on ffnet for When the Evidence Lies.  The review said "Okay, that's it. I'm done with this. Do you realize it's been 16 months since you updated. The least you could do is post that the story is on hiatus. From now on, when and if I read stories on this list, they better say "complete," or I won't be bothering. Can you really think anyone will take you seriously after you do this?"  My initial impulse which was to just delete When the Evidence Lies once and for all; some days that story seems like more trouble than its worth.  Instead I posted on YTDAW's Reader's and Writer's Rant thread and I'm following the advice I got and let the snarky comment roll off my back. 

Also I have found a novel series that might be of interest; its not too new, but I'd never heard of it until I found it in the library.  Its from various authors writing under the name Alex Archer and called Rogue Angel.  Without giving away the plot its kinda like Witchblade meets Lara Croft.  The heroine is interesting and the writers apparently watch the same documentaries I do because the archaeology stuff was both familiar and pretty accurate.  I finished the first book "Destiny" and have checked out the next three, though according to Wikipedia there are a bunch published and like 10 more coming.

This has been an interesting week filled with various health tests.  Last Friday I was seen by the Doctor because I developed a muscle spasm in my left arm, finally calling for an appointment after if had been twitching and jumping for 36 hours.  The result was predictable, the Doc has no clue, would like to run some more tests (see if my electralights were balanced) and offered me a muscle relaxing med to see if it would help.  I agreed to the tests, but skipped the meds.  I have more than enough chemicals in my system for now without adding more to the cocktail.  The spasm eventually went away on its own the following Sunday.

I woke up with a migraine on Monday, but rather than call in sick decided to work remote from home and face the potential fall out from that later.  I ended up being able to complete my shift, especially after taking a nap for my lunch hour.  I also mentioned to a co-worker my frustration at the system and got her side of the story on why she can work from home when she wants.  She was shocked to hear that I was still "sick," apparently I haven't been complaining about it enough, but I don't see any point troubling them when i have no solid information.  She did begin to see the seriousness of it when I mentioned that I was undergoing 2 EEGs and an MRI this week. 

So the title is a reference to those procedures.  The EEGs weren't too bad they use this cold jelly like glue to attach electrodes all over your head and a few on your face.  The test is designed to monitor my brain waves both awake and asleep, which was followed up by the audio and visual eeg tests, basically I listened to a series of clicks or watched a screen of dancing squares and apparently the waves and spikes recorded will tell my neurologist what's going on. 


The MRI I took today should also help with the diagnosis, which is what I kept telling myself through out the most hellish procedure ever.  First off I should explain that I am not a skinny person, at best I'm Rubensque with a large bust and with my existing claustrophobia they had to put me in the open MRI machine, the regular one would have been a squeeze.  So because they were doing a brain scan they had to put this "cage" on.  Boy that was tough like having my own version of Man in The Iron Mask moment.  Luckily between relaxation techniques and medications I managed to get through the experience; it was tough by the end I was panicked, crying and desperately wanted to stop, but was determined to make it through.

I wonder what the results will say since I had episodes of the tingling and shocks during the tests, my hope it will clarify things for the doctor, but I don't see him until July 10th.  In the meantime I'm patiently taking my medications though each time I pray that the side effects will be better and basically keeping my chin up.  It helped that a few days ago I saw part of a Montel Williams show which was talking about improving your health.  I've been reminding myself that he took his MS diagnosis and used it to create a better, healthier life.  I still don't know what the docs are considering beyond epilepsy, though the eeg tech made a couple comments in passing about how the MRI would check for myelin sheath degeneration.  At this point all I can do is wait for what the Doctor has to say.

Today when my fear was so overwhelming a voice whispered in my mind, perhaps my brain pulling out a quote to help, whatever it was the reminder I needed and I'm employing it each time thoughts and fear of what this could be occur.

I must not fear.
Fear is the mind-killer.
Fear is the little-death that brings total obliteration.
I will face my fear.
I will permit it to pass over me and through me.
And when it has gone past I will turn the inner eye to see its path.
Where the fear has gone there will be nothing.
Only I will remain.
             Bene Gesserit Litany Against Fear

Warning: fanfic rant
After reading the YTDAW long lost writers thread to get the scope on why a particular author left the fandom and deleted all her accounts and stories I found myself very irritated at the reasons.  Let me qualify this by explaining I am NOT upset with the author, they are her stories, her identity and her right to do with them as she chooses.  I am however upset with the people behind her reasons.  She expressed concern about her conservative employers discovering her hobby.  The fact that she has to be concerned about losing her employment/profession because of her internet activity irks me to no end.  Its that fact that in this free country, our right to free speech can be hindered by fear because in my mind its a form of censorship.  Perhaps even the worst kind of censorship because it is making the author ban her own work from public view.  Perhaps I am naive about the real world, blame it on my California liberal upbringing, but it isn't right or fair for that to happen.

That being said, knowing that there might be a background investigation in my future if I get that job with the City I am now suddenly afraid and I don't like it one bit.  Now don't get in a panic, or anything, I maybe a little bit worried now, but I have no intention to remove myself from the fandom.  Its funny the thought that they might hold my writing against me actually makes me want to fight the system while the rest of me just points out that when G-d closes a door, another opens and I can't get so focused on the "negative" loss of opportunity that I miss the wonderful new one presenting itself.
